citations.narrative:
On August 29, 2023 "Bucky" a White-throated woodrat, had his tail caught in a door of his primary enclosure during
transfer by a keeper. The animal was evaluated by a veterinarian promptly and determined that no medical care was
necessary. During veterinary examination on September 22, 2023 for a separate medical procedure, it was found that
Bucky had a scab encircling his tail due to trauma from an undetermined cause. Medical treatment and monitoring was
initiated with the eventual outcome of a partial tail amputation. The facility reported a summary of these events to an
APHIS Official. Failure to handle animals as carefully as possible may result in trauma to animals or unnecessary
discomfort. Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not
cause trauma, behavioral stress, physical harm or unnecessary discomfort.
Correct from this date forward of 15 March 2024.

Multiple enclosures for birds have sections that are heavily rusted. These areas include:
•Rust present on the metal wall of one of the Western Screech-Owl's outdoor enclosure in the Interpretive Animal
Collection. Some of the rust is actively flaking off to which the bird has access.
•Diffuse orange rust present in a quadrant of the wire and pole roof of the outdoor enclosure for "Bowie" a Red-tailed
Hawk.
•Diffuse orange rusting of a majority of the wire and pole roof for "BlueBarry" a White-throated Magpie-jay.
Failure to maintain housing facilities in good repair may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Housing facilities
for birds must be kept in good repair to protect the birds from injury and to allow proper cleaning of interior surfaces.
Correct by 1 April 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
On August 29, 2023 "Bucky" a White-throated woodrat, had his tail caught in a door of his primary enclosure during 
transfer by a keeper. The animal was evaluated by a veterinarian promptly and determined that no medical care was 
necessary. During veterinary examination on September 22, 2023 for a separate medical procedure, it was found that 
Bucky had a scab encircling his tail due to trauma from an undetermined cause. Medical treatment and monitoring was 
initiated with the eventual outcome of a partial tail amputation. The facility reported a summary of these events to an 
APHIS Official. Failure to handle animals as carefully as possible may result in trauma to animals or unnecessary 
discomfort. Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not 
cause trauma, behavioral stress, physical harm or unnecessary discomfort.  
Correct from this date forward of 15 March 2024. 
3.150(c)(2) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Multiple enclosures for birds have sections that are heavily rusted. These areas include: 
•Rust present on the metal wall of one of the Western Screech-Owl's outdoor enclosure in the Interpretive Animal 
Collection. Some of the rust is actively flaking off to which the bird has access. 
•Diffuse orange rust present in a quadrant of the wire and pole roof of the outdoor enclosure for "Bowie" a Red-tailed 
Hawk. 
•Diffuse orange rusting of a majority of the wire and pole roof for "BlueBarry" a White-throated Magpie-jay.  
Failure to maintain housing facilities in good repair may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Housing facilities 
for birds must be kept in good repair to protect the birds from injury and to allow proper cleaning of interior surfaces. 
Correct by 1 April 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
